summary_of_attack: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has caused around $3.5 billion worth of damage to the country's heritage and cultural sites, a United Nations agency reported on Feb. 13. According to UNESCO, which used satellite images to assess the damage, some 5,000 sites have been destroyed, including more than 340 sites such as museums, monuments, libraries and religious venues. Two UNESCO World Heritage sites, the medieval center of the western city of Lviv and Odesa in the south, were among those hit hard by Russian strikes, including the Transfiguartion Cathedral in Odesa.

Russians Destroy And Damage 1,987 Cultural Sites In Ukraine
summary_of_attack: As of April 25, 2024, 1,987 cultural institutions In Ukraine were damaged or destroyed due to Russia’s full-scale aggression. Russian attacks damaged or destroyed 30 state-owned cultural institutions (12% of the total number of institutions of the basic network at the national level) and 1,957 municipally-owned sites (6% of the total number of institutions of the basic network at the local level).  The largest group of cultural institutions that suffered damage or devastation were club institutions. In total, enemy strikes destroyed or damaged 958 club facilities, 708 libraries, 153 art education facilities, 114 museums and galleries, 36 theaters, cinemas and philharmonic halls, 15 parks, zoos and nature reserves, as well as three circuses.

article_header: Ukraine denounces 242 Russian war crimes against its cultural heritage
summary_of_attack: Broadly details Russian damage to Ukraine cultural sites: 242 episodes of war crimes against Ukrainian cultural heritage committed by Russian forces in the capital Kiev. Breaking it down by region, Kharkov (84 recorded episodes) and Donetsk (45),  recorded the most damage, followed by the Kyiv metropolitan region which recorded 38 episodes of damage. In total, 94 cultural heritage sites were destroyed or damaged since the beginning of the invasion on February 24, including 16 monuments of national importance, 72 of local importance and six identified only as cultural heritage.Religious centers were the most targeted by Russian forces, with 92 buildings destroyed or damaged, including Orthodox churches, Protestant places of worship, mosques and synagogues, of which 35 are considered historical, architectural and urban monuments. the damaged objects include 29 memorials honoring historical persons and events from the 19th to the beginning of the 21st centuries, 19 museum and reserve buildings and complexes, 33 cultural centers, theaters and libraries, as well as some other valuable historical buildings.

summary_of_attack: The UNESCO confirmed damage to 53 Ukrainian historical sites, religious buildings and museums during the Russian invasion. Over a dozen in the eastern Kharkiv region have been intensely hit by Russian fire, ranging from churches to more modern heritage sites. The Russians destroyed a local history museum in the Kyiv region, bombed a drama theatre in Mariupol, a southern port city besieged by Moscow for nearly a month, and damaged a Holocaust memorial in Kharkiv in eastern Ukraine.

The list of monuments in Ukraine includes well over 3,000 monuments. Cultural sites in the Donetsk region were hit hardest (63), followed by the Kharkiv (53), Kiev (32), Luhansk (26) and Chernihiv (15) regions. In total, Unesco recorded damage at 218 sites.

summary_of_attack: Since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, 1,062 monuments of cultural heritage have been damaged or destroyed, including 316 monuments of architecture and urban planning, as well as architecture (307), history (226), architecture and urban planning, history (61), archeology (56), architecture, history (39), monumental art (21), urban planning and monumental decorative arts (19), architecture, monumental art (7), urban planning (5), science and technology, architecture (2), architecture and urban planning, monumental art (1), architecture and landscape (1); architecture, gardens and parks (1), with the largest number of monuments of cultural heritage was affected in Kharkiv region (299), Kherson region (144), Donetsk region (125), Odesa region (115), Chernihiv region (71), as well as 69 in Kyiv region and Kyiv. Cultural heritage sites sustained damage in the region of Mykolayiv (44 monuments), Zaporizhzhia (44), Lviv (36), Dnipropetrovsk (34), Luhansk (30), Sumy (25), Khmelnytskyi (10), Poltava (6), Vinnytsia (4), Zhytomyr (4), Kirovohrad (1), and Cherkasy (1).

article_header: Due To War In Ukraine 763 Cultural Heritage Sites Damaged
summary_of_attack:
During the period from February 24, 2022 to July 25, 2023, 763 cultural heritage sites were damaged or destroyed. Of these, 105 are objects of national importance, 595 are of local importance, and 63 are newly discovered.
The monuments of architecture include 241 objects, architecture and urban planning - 218, history - 185, architecture and history - 28, monumental art - 19, urban planning and monumental art - 17, archeology - 18, architecture, urban planning, and history - 27, urban planning - 5, science and technology - 2, landscape art - 1, architecture, urban planning, and monumental art - 1, architecture and monumental art - 1. Most of the cultural heritage sites were damaged in Kharkiv, Donetsk and Kherson regions.

summary_of_attack: Flooding following the destruction of the Kakhovka Dam has destroyed significant archaeological sites. Churches, monuments and museums are submerged all over the Kherson region. Archaeological sites dating back to the Scythians — a nomadic people who lived in the region in the 8th century BC — and a Greek settlement from around 400 BC have been damaged or irretrievably destroyed. A  museum honoring writer and humorist Ostap Vyshnya, which was not restored until 2020, and the Kherson Art Museum, named after painter Oleksii Shovkunenko, remain flooded as well. In the flooded town of Oleshky, the former residence of folk artist Polina Rayko had been damaged by the water as well.

Specialist gang ‘targeting’ Ukrainian treasures for removal to Russia
summary_of_attack: A specialist gang is smuggling valuable historic artefacts out of Ukraine and into Russia. The trail of thefts focuses heavily on precious Scythian gold. These are high-worth ancient filigree pieces, often depicting animals. They were produced by tribes of the area of central Asia and eastern Europe once known as Scythia. The thefts tend to follow the menacing interrogation of museum curators and custodians. Russian attempts to locate and steal hidden artefacts in occupied Ukrainian cities are becoming more determined.

summary_of_attack: As of August 29, 2023, a total of 1,624 cultural infrastructure objects suffered damage, not including cultural heritage monuments. Almost a third of them (591 objects) have been destroyed. In total, 769 art clubs, 610 libraries, 93 museums and galleries, 30 theaters and philharmonic halls, as well as 122 art education facilities, were affected. Club facilities, libraries, museums, theaters, philharmonic societies, art schools and colleges, and objects of cultural heritage were damaged or destroyed on the territory of 230 territorial communities (15.7% of all). Most - in Donetsk (87%), Sumy (51%), Luhansk, and Mykolaiv regions (42% each). At the same time, 37% of cultural heritage sites were damaged or destroyed in Kherson region, 36% in Kharkiv region, 33% in Zaporizhzhia region, 29% in Kyiv region, 18% in Dnipropetrovsk region, 16% in Chernihiv region, 12% in Zhytomyr region, 8% in Khmelnytskyi region, 6% in Odesa region, 4% in Lviv region, 3% in Vinnytsia region, 3% in Cherkasy region, and 2% in Zakarpattia region.

summary_of_attack: Ukraine's Ministry of Culture denounced having documented 242 episodes of war crimes against Ukrainian cultural heritage committed by Russian forces in the capital Kiev and at least 11 of the country's 24 provinces.  94 cultural heritage sites were destroyed or damaged since the beginning of the invasion on February 24, including 16 monuments of national importance, 72 of local importance and six identified only as cultural heritage. Religious centers were the most targeted by Russian forces, with 92 buildings destroyed or damaged, including Orthodox churches, Protestant places of worship, mosques and synagogues, of which 35 are considered historical, architectural and urban monuments. The ministry also added that the damaged objects include 29 memorials honoring historical persons and events from the 19th to the beginning of the 21st centuries, 19 museum and reserve buildings and complexes, 33 cultural centers, theaters and libraries, as well as some other valuable historical buildings.

Cultural resources such as repositories of Ukrainian literature, museums, and historical archives are being destroyed, and there is a widespread narrative of demonisation and denigration of Ukrainian culture and identity promoted by Russian officials, along with calls for ideological repression and strict censorship in the political, cultural and educational spheres. Efforts are being made to erase local culture, history, and language in cultural and educational institutions and to forcibly replace them with Russian language and with Russian and Soviet history and culture. Ukrainian history books and literature deemed to be "extremist" have been seized from public libraries in cities and towns in the occupied territory of Luhansk, Donetsk, Chernihiv, and Sumy Oblasts and destroyed by the occupying power. The same has been reported about school history manuals in certain cities.

article_header: Russian missiles damaged seven museums in Kiev
summary_of_attack:
A Russian missile fell near the science library of the Taras Shevchenko National University, while another hit near the Shevchenko Park which is close to the Khanenko Museum.  In addition to the university library, other sites that were affected include the National Academy of Sciences, the National Philharmonic, the Pedagogical Museum of Ukraine, the Ukrainian Museum of the Revolution 1917-1921, at the Khanenko Museum several windows were broken, as well as at the Kyiv Picture Gallery, the National Research and Restoration Center, the Museum-Apartment of Mykola Platonovych Bazhan and Pavlo Tychyna, and the Kyiv Museum of History.
Russia was accused of setting fire to a museum near Kyiv, destroying about 25 paintings by artist Maria Pryimachenko, and in May, Ukraine said Russia looted more than 2,000 works of art. On Oct. 10, UNESCO verified damage to 201 Ukrainian heritage sites since the Feb. 24 Russian invasion,

summary_of_attack:
Russian troops carted away the priceless crown of Attila the Hun and a hoard of other treasures after capturing the Ukrainian city of Melitopol in February 2022. 
Russian soldiers helped themselves to artefacts in almost 40 Ukrainian museums. The looting and destruction of cultural sites has caused losses estimated in the hundreds of millions of dollars. 
Other treasures that disappeared include 198 pieces of 2,400-year-old gold from the era of the Scythians, nomads who migrated from Central Asia to southern Russia and Ukraine and founded an empire in Crimea.

article_header: UNESCO: 274 cultural sites damaged in Ukraine due to Russian invasion
summary_of_attack:
UNESCO has verified damage to 274 sites since 24 February 2022 - 117 religious sites, 27 museums, 98 buildings of historical and/or artistic interest, 19 monuments, 12 libraries, 1 archive. he largest number of such objects were affected in Donetsk (78), Kharkiv (55), Kyiv (38), Luhansk (33), and Chernihiv (17) regions. Also, damage was recorded in Zaporizhzhia and Sumy regions (12 objects each), Odesa and Mykolayiv regions (8 each), Kherson (6), Zhytomyr (3), Vinnytsia (2), Dnipropetrovsk and Lviv regions (one each).

According to the Ministry of Culture and Information Policy of Ukraine, 1,605 objects of cultural infrastructure have been damaged or destroyed as a result of the full-scale invasion.

summary_of_attack:
Russian occupiers destroyed the historic building of the Museum of Local Lore in the village. Ivankiv in the Kyiv region. The bombing almost completely destroyed the building of the Donetsk Academic Regional Drama Theater in Mariupol. The buildings of the A. Kuindzhi Mariupol Art Museum and the Museum of Local Lore in Okhtyrka in the Sumy Region were damaged. As a result of the rocket bombing of Kharkiv, the Kharkiv Regional State Administration was destroyed, the obelisk-menorah of the Holocaust Memorial in Drobitsky Gorge and many other monuments were damaged.
Religious buildings suffered the most - 59 objects. Among them: Orthodox churches of the Orthodox Church of Ukraine and the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate, Protestant houses of worship, Islamic mosques, Jewish synagogues.
58 cultural heritage sites were destroyed and damaged by the occupiers. These are monuments of architecture and urban planning. Among them 5 are monuments of national importance. 25 valuable objects of historical buildings were damaged - ancient buildings of the second half of the XIX - early XX centuries, as well as 10 monuments - memorial stelae or sculptures related to historical events.
12 museums and historical and architectural reserves, 6 theaters and cinemas, 5 libraries were damaged.

Crimes were recorded in 10 regions of Ukraine and in Kyiv: 54 - in Kharkiv region; 22 - in Donetsk; 16 - in Chernihiv; 10 - in Kyiv; 9 - in Luhansk; 9 - in Sumy; 5 - in the city of Kyiv; 4 - in Zaporizhia; 4 - in Zhytomyr region; 1 - in Dnipropetrovsk; 1 - in the Kherson regions.
